posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: Is there any way to send UDP data to the abbreviation 'DS' with a tool tip text 'Driver Station'? I suppose that the controller sends a message from the robot to ds via UDP, is there a method to create a UDP receiver acting as a fake controller that can receive multiple inputs?
Can you clarify what you're trying to do? Are you trying to send data to the FRC Driver Station or the laptop (using Network Tables instead)? This seems like an XY problem.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: The protocol has been reverse-engineered. The key takeaway is that it consists of multiple streams of data presented in a specific format expected by the driver station. The entity at the other end must function like a comprehensive roboRIO, capable of handling inputs beyond a single joystick. Over the past few weeks, I attempted to create a system that would appear as a regular roboRIO to the driver station. While partial success was achieved—the driver station could interact with and control the system—I encountered difficulties in fully integrating it, particularly when transmitting detailed joystick data within the allocated time frame. A significant challenge was ensuring proper packet sequencing and data integrity, as the driver station did not provide feedback on errors related to this process, making debugging particularly challenging. At its core, this appears to be an X/Y problem, where focusing on solving the symptoms rather than addressing the root cause led to complications. To summarize, the system comprises multiple streams of data formatted specifically for the driver station, and achieving seamless functionality requires robust error handling and precise synchronization mechanisms.

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: send data to the laptop using udp rather than tcp to increase transfer speed

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: I want software that can create a fake DS which will be detected by the DS, enabling communication via UDP to a rio, potentially using the same approach as Controller Rumble.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: R704 lays out what ports are open for team usage. It includes some UDP ports. TCP with NO_DELAY over an already-established TCP connection isn’t wildly higher-latency, especially in the context of anything that runs in a 20ms overall Rio loop. Absent packet loss, it is higher latency than UDP, but it’s also reliable (eventually) in the face of packet loss.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: Now this is my professional gig as a manager for a team that develops some of the world's fastest commercial messaging software. For our purposes here in FRC, the speed difference between UDP and TCP is basically non-existent—we routinely benchmark to many millions of messages per second over TCP professionally, so it’s not a protocol limitation on a network that doesn’t suffer from significant loss. Once loss begins happening, UDP isn’t any faster than TCP (in a practical sense); it’s the guaranteed delivery of TCP that gives you priority. You know good-fast-cheap; pick two? The same goes for TCP—you trade guaranteed delivery and ordering for determinism, meaning you have to wait for a retransmission because you implicitly asked for guaranteed delivery and ordering. This looks like it’s slowing your perceived throughput. With UDP, you’re just dropping packets, which isn’t helping throughput either (though you are getting what didn’t get lost promptly if you do receive it). The difference between the two is that with UDP, your stream won’t block; you’ll just lose data. Sounds challenging, but it might not be if you consider the use case. If you can tolerate loss, UDP can keep your data timely, though you’d need robust mechanisms to handle it at the application level. Just from your high-level points, that’s likely your primary concern here rather than speed of transfer, as the handshake overhead is minimal compared to the rest of the communication. The key with UDP is that you won’t experience blocking. If TCP message streams are delayed due to loss, your UDP communications will also face loss—no free lunch. However, if you successfully receive a UDP packet, it’s almost certainly “fresh(ish)” because it either arrives quickly or not at all. This isn’t guaranteed, especially with intermediate network devices. If you design your packet stream to handle loss gracefully, you might gain more deterministic performance using UDP. That requires careful consideration of what you send and how your application handles data loss; for instance, sensors sending delta values need redundancy mechanisms like sending absolute messages periodically. Scalar values like RPM can handle loss, but you might sacrifice some timeliness for data integrity. In the end, TCP and UDP don’t control transfer speed—they rely on IP, which is network-dependent and prone to loss. There’s no magic bit to set on a packet for super-fast, loss-free transmission. Without knowing specific requirements, it’s hard to advise, but generally, avoiding blocking with TCP might lead you to choose UDP if loss tolerance is feasible. However, you must ensure your application can handle loss without compromising functionality. There are reliable UDP alternatives like Google’s QUIC, which offer flexible loss management compared to rigid TCP protocols.工程上有个重要原则：没有免费午餐。 Many people overlook what they ordered and get surprised by the bill.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]

posts.name: 6894 Lead prog/driver
posts.cooked: Wow thank you so much Our use case was initially to display queues to the driver over audio but using networktables introduced a .3-second delay causing issues since we intended it as a queue for the drivers. The system will simply handle booleans indicating two states without significant loss affecting functionality. If loss doesn’t impact performance it could simplify implementation further. TCP appears suitable as it avoids unnecessary complexity.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked: It will just be booleans, I’m not fully sure how loss works in terms of that, but if it’s a boolean that toggles between 2 states I feel like loss will not be bad on its effectiveness. I think you nailed that - you can consider a “boolean” to basically be an absolute state so each message is complete and doesn’t depend on any other message. If you get it, that was the state when it was sent. If you don’t get it, well, you wait for the next one - but you can control how frequently those get sent. It’s all about knowing what you want to do and figuring out what the implications and requirements are. Sounds like you did that - kudos. Given what you described, UDP might be best. Do you care what the state was X seconds ago or do you want the latest? That will drive just about everything for you. Good luck!
